Wall mount for filament spools. It's just long enough to hold three spools. I tested this for 7.5 pounds placed at the end using some weights and it didn't complain. Could probably carry more weight and could be optimized, I'm sure.

Inspired by blazejudo's "Filament wall mount v1.3", but about half an inch longer and it's much easier to print due to the arm being the same with as the base plate.

Haven't had any issues with v1, but a weak print of blazejudo's version failed after a few months, so I've modified this with some new techniques. v2 should be pretty strong already, but if you want to make it stronger, you can insert a screw and washer from the wall side before you put it up.

I haven't printed v2 yet due to Christmas using all my print time.

description.text:
A weather-resistant housing for sparkfun's PIR motion sensor:
https://www.sparkfun.com/products/8630 ...the idea being to join together many water-resistant PIR sensors in a long daisy chain with cat5 cable and connectors. There is a huge gulf between "water resistant" and "water proof", Caulk everything. The sensor in particular needs caulk to stay put. Improvements from 0.0.1 include
a) A lid that actually prints, and even snaps on securely
b) Keyed cat5 receptors that rotate less in the main housing (Not perfect)
c) Made the housing roomier just by rotating the sensor 90 degrees

I print these on Makerbot's "medium" setting with 1 shell.  They come out pretty sturdy, and usually don't need much if any cleanup.  
You will need to caulk in the PIR sensor at the very least, it won't sit securely without it.  
You may want to remove the 'fin' from the lid before snapping it on, to make it more flexible.  It's there to stabilize the print.  
The threaded cat5 jack holders have spots in them to hold the guts from those cheap beige rj45 couplers you can find anywhere.

comments.text: If you're silicone caulking, then use electronics-safe (or mirror-safe, which is cheaper and easier to find in hardware stores) silicone.

Anyone interested in the work of Daniel Noreé has probably not missed the fact that he soon will release the files for his latest project - OpenR/C Formula 1. The F1 car can be printed in PLA and is designed so that everybody will be able to print and build it without any hassle. Even a ball bearing kit is now available http://www.fasteddybearings.com/openrc-f1-sealed-bearing-kit/ for the car :- )

I happen to know that Daniel is extremely close to a release of the awesome F1 car and I obviously had to create some tires for that project. So if you plan to print the F1-car when it´s released here is the possibility to be prepared with some new tires in the pit stop already now.
I created some rain tires for the original rims but I also designed a set of low profile rim/tires just for fun. The low profile tires feature a new snap-on design that will secure the tire using a triangular shape that´s interconnecting the parts. Also the tires are not sealed with this design, making them a bit softer since the air is not trapped inside.

Also check http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1103751

This snap-on design is also available for tires/rims that can be used with the OpenR/C Touring Car or similar RC cars naturally.

Download the Touring rims here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001223 and the tires here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001233

Enjoy!

Please also check out my unuiqe UV-stable, flexible and conductive filament called ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black filament.

Don´t need the conductivity? Well the conductivity is great for some things but perhaps not your first choice? Then consider this:

This filament will give you some really nice benefits if the conductivity is not an disadvantage for your 3D printed design:

•The material composition eliminates “stringing / webbing” issues.
•The hardness of 95 shore A and the carbon black filler makes for great print abilities.
•The carbon black filler is an excellent UV stabilizer thus the prints are built to last in very harsh environments.
•The matte black surface finish has a very exclusive look.
•The material feels very nice and dry to touch.
•It´s not too stretchy and will do great for timing belts etc.

comments.text: How is the grip, and overall softness of the tire (in terms as cushioning bumps) between your filament (PI-ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black) with a shore hardness of 95A and that of what Daniel recommends printing the tires out of ( Ninjaflex) with a shore hardness of 85A?
comments.author: Puredeath

comments.text: I would say none of them have a very good grip compared to molded standard tires from the store. 85 Shore A is definitely softer than 95, thus the tire is softer. Ninjaflex is glossy and ETPU 95-250 has a matte surface (I think it looks more like the real thing) and easier to print (if your printer is not optimized for soft materials that is) and its UV-stable (but that is no issue for ware-parts like tires right). The conclusion is that they both have pros & cons and its up to everyone to decide what is best for them. KR Thomas

comments.text: I changed over to Hatchbox filament. I haven't had a single failure since. The M3d filament has little air bubbles in it causing uneven flow and failures. Some of the colors you can see the bubbles when held up to a light. You have to look at a pretty long piece to catch it. Hatchbox is $22 pr roll on amazon, but the rolls are twice as big, so actually is a couple of bucks cheaper than M3d. I will shoot a pic of the spool holder I'm using with it later.

description.text: A stylized holder for your dental or office instruments.

A mount to add bearings and a spring to a caliper so you can measure filament as it runs between the bearings.  There is a mounting arm so you can add it to a filament winder, or set it up between two spools to check the size or deviation of some filament.  It works best if you have some good guidance for the filament before and after the caliper, because the filament will tend to slip off  the bearings to one side or the other.   
Update:  
I added a version that has a built in filament guide and a wider mounting plate.

In addition to the printed parts you will need: 4" Pittsburgh caliper from Harbor Freight
2 608 bearings
2 M8 x 20 bolts
2 M8 Nuts
4 small sharp screws
1 small spring, about 1.5" long. The part with the mounting arm goes on the fixed jaw of the caliper, and the smaller part goes on the sliding part. There are small starter holes for the screws which hold the spring. You can try to drill through the steel caliper jaws, but I found that loading it up with superglue works fine. Just make sure that the bearings stay flat and aligned with each other. If one ends up cocked at a little bit of an angle, it will push the filament out to one side and the measurement will change as the filament moves from one side of the bearing to another.

description.text: Kettle designed by industrial design Pratt student James Fisk
Man face

Secure your laptop to the back of your monitor to keep it out of the way and off your desk. Uses the standard monitor mounting screws. I found a very solid VESA universal monitor mount, and then molded it to be a general use laptop bracket. It was made to be very simple to print, very strong, and somewhat versatile for fit.

Updated: (9-2-2016) As of the Aug 31st I made the base lighter using less materials. It should be just as strong, but it uses 21% material. It is my hope to make everything stronger and lighter. Using less material should benefit with a faster print as well.

Special thanks to User Moore from Sydney - Australia, he made the nice snug fit VESA mount I modified. Feedback is always welcome!

Print on a 3D printer on normal setting. Mount is made to print flat. I have included two sizes of laptop holding arms with a slide the will work that even if your printer is slightly off with sizes. It should hold a 15" laptop with ease, I re-made this mount to be very sturdy.

title: Polaroid Land Camera Cable Release Adapter

description.text:
This is an adapter so that you can use a standard photography cable release on a Polaroid Land Camera. It should work on any model of Land Camera, but it definitely works great on my 250.

You will need a steel nut that goes inside of the print. I am still working out the best thread pitch to match the standard cable release. Right now I'm using a standard 3/8" pitch nut, which is the same thread as a tripod mount. That works fine, but I've read that M4 might thread better, so this is still a work-in-progress.

I will also upload two versions when I'm done. One for embedding the nut into the print (if your printer has pausing capabilities), and one with an open bottom so that you can just superglue or epoxy the nut into the print.

Here's a gif of the cable release in action! http://i.imgur.com/QfxOQrb.gif

If you want to embed the nut into the print, pause the print before and insert the nut before that portion of the print finishes.

I will put specifics up about the nut soon.

comments.text:
Nice! It is so wonderful to see someone working in the realm of making vintage film photography easier.
I was wondering - have you ever thought of making a 6x12cm film back for Polaroid 110a/b? If you check into this subject, you will see that these were amazing cameras with a great lens, but the film they used has not been in production for at least two decades. Now there are people creating 4x5 backs for this camera, but there is nothing in the medium format panoramic area for this camera. You could be the first, you could sell the files online, on ebay for a reasonable price and have a ton of buyers. 4x5 inch backs are expensive, but they are not rare any more, but 6x12 cm backs are nowhere to be found. You could be the first to come up with them.
What do you think?

comments.text: I definitely love the combination of modern tech and vintage photography, so I love the idea, but unfortunately I don't even have a 3d printer big enough at the moment. Maybe some day...

title: Magnetic Bowden Extruder X Axis Carriage

description.text:
What is it?

I've bought 100pcs of magnets 3mm : 1mm, so i've tried to find a job for them. The goal is to implement a method for easy release extruder, with 15 magnets on each side.

Does it work?

I still have no idea since i've never printed it, gonna try it out as soon as possible and write down a feedback in case it works (hope so). If somebody ever tried a similar method, please let me know.

What do you need for it?

  • 15xS-03-01-N Magnets
  • 4xLM8U linear bearing
  • 1xTop_Side_Carriage.stl
  • 1xBottom_Side_Carriage.stl
  • 1xHotend_Carriage.stl

Future Updates/Mods:

  • Conic holes for easily stick inside the magnets
  • Double magnetic carriage for double extruder
  • Possibility to carry laser for engraving, pencil and more
  • Implement Y Axis

 

Changelog:

  • Published on Sep 4, 2015
  • Added GT2 Belt Clamp on Sep 6, 2015 


Feel free to comment, ask, and (whynot?) to try it out leaving a feedback so to optimize project.

09/06/2015 :

News Side part

Description:

On classic spool holders, there is a risk that the spool unrolls too much when the 3D printer pulls the filament.

With my spool holder, the spool will unroll only the length needed.

Explanation:

On the side view, the filament is showed in black.

First, the filament rolls freely between the green and pink rolls (upper ones).

As the filament is pulled to the top, it exerts a force on the lower pink roll.

This force is pivoting counterclockwise both the 2 pink rolls as well as the 2 orange levers.

The filament is then caught between the green and pink rolls.

By friction, the filament carries the green roll along which in turn unrolls the spool by using the other gears - purple, blue, red, and then yellow.

When unrolling, the spool loosens the filament, therefore the force exerted on the lower pink roll. As a consequence, the filament is not caught anymore. It does not carry along the green roll, which does not unroll the spool anymore.

The process goes again and repeats itself endlessly.

Comments:

Gears multiply the force. As a consequence, only a small force is needed on the green roll for rolling the spool.

The lower legs of the 2 orange levers are thin. Therefore they are insuring a spring and regulator effect for absorbing the filament violent jolts.

This also insures that the system does not work backwards. Roll and gear dimensions are calculated for a spool with a wound filament diameter less than 200mm.

Improvements:

The spring effect of the two levers can be modified by changing their leg thickness.

The green roll adhesion can be improved by covering it with rubber.
All components can be assembled with 4mm diameter axis (in red on some pictures) – M4 screw, threaded shaft, etc.

remixed_from.author: marcotronic
remixed_from.title: Rocket BIC Pen for Wacom Intuos3 Pen Holder

description.text:
After two failed attempts to print the Rocket BIC Pen for Wacom Intous3 Pen Holder by marcotronic (model would keep getting knocked over being so tall without enough support for my printer), I decided to break it up into a couple parts. The .STL file would not render correctly in OpenSCAD so I decided to just create my own version based on their design. This allows each piece to be printed in different colors if desired.

The opening for the pen in the original model was too large for the pen cartridge I had. So figuring others might have different sizes too, I included the OpenSCAD file for the top so different size openings can be made.

I have included the Wacom Intuos3 Pen Holder by JamesRX for completeness.

comments.text: Good job!
comments.author: marcotronic

description.text:
NOTE: All files were modelled in inches. If your software shows the parts as a very small size, scale the model by 25.4 to get it to the proper size, or set the dimensions to inches.

This thing is a fully printable, fully expandable, and modular filament spool holder. The holder can be printed in full using a printer with at least 12x10" (305mmx254mm) capabilities. If your printer is smaller than that, I've uploaded a second version which is identical to the first except made with interlocking studs in four parts, allowing you to print this thing using a printer with 7x5" (178mmx127mm) capabilities! That is a whole lot of spool holding for only a little space! Some of the great aspects of this design are:

-Fully Modular. If you want to hold ten spools you just need to increase the space between end caps.

-Separate Compartments. If you want to mount different plastics, just print an extra endcap and add it on. No need for a redesign!

-Modular footprint. While this particular thing has about a 10"x8" footprint, you can add or subtract depending on your needs.

-Less plastic and less money. The cutouts in this design not only look good, they save plastic and time too!

-Stylish. The cutouts and curves of the design make it visually appealing in your work station.

-Easy Carry and Breakdown. This thing has built in handles so you can just pick it up and go.

-Tool-less Assembly/Disassembly. No tools required to build this thing! And if you ever want to break it down or change spools, it takes less than 2 minutes and no tools!

-Unlimited hub size capacity. This thing was optimized for Makerbot "Large" size spools, however any spool will fit. Simply alter the Outer Diameter of the spool hub bushing for the size of your hub hole, print, and get back to business as usual!

-Tangle-Free Filament Guide. With a build in filament guide, your prints will never be ruined due to tangled or broken filament. The guides keep everything organized so you don't have to stress!

This spool holder is the last you'll ever need. Easy to print, completely customizable, visually appealing, and small, you never need to change spool holders again, even if you change printers! Plus, this holder is built for an on-the-go lifestyle. Simply pick up and go with the built in handles! And you can leave your spool on. Finally, the filament guide prevents tangles and leaves you stress-free when printing for long periods of time.

Print one for yourself and see how easy it is!

I was looking for a modular spool holder that didn't take up much room, and I couldn't find one that was easily printable. So I made one!

At first I made each end one piece, but I realized most people don't have a huge print area, so I redesigned it to be four pieces under 6x6" so most people could enjoy it.

author: rogwabbit

title: Bare Essentials Spool Holder and No-Tangle Filament Cuff

description.text:
You need a spool holder, and you need it fast! This minimalist spool holder prints in minutes, not hours. Just jam 608 skate bearings (you must have some of those lying around) onto the ends of 2 Bic pens (check the sofa cushions) and then snap the bearings into the ends of the holder -- that's it! There are no widths to adjust, no careful positioning of feet, no screwing anything to the wall or table - just plop your spool on and go. The rim-rider design keeps the filament safely captured within the confines of the spool, with no nooks or crannies for the filament to get caught in.

But wait, there's more! If you print this spool holder today, you can also print up this No-Tangle Filament Cuff! Slip this springy cuff over your new roll of filament and leave it there until the roll is done -- it just rides along with your filament while you print and then keeps your filament tidy while in storage. The wrap-around design prevents the filament end from getting tangled up under the loose outer wraps. It's easily scale-able for any width or diameter spool.

Here's a short video of the FIlament Cuff in action: https://youtu.be/UXnvW-nb--o

Spool holder:

  • Print the 2 spool holder parts with 4 shells, 0.4mm line width and 0% infill.
  • Pull the ends off of two Bic "round stic" pens. (Papermate pens are too small.)
  • Press one 608 skate bearing (4 total) on the end of each pen tube.
  • Snap the bearings into the ends of the spool holders and start printing!

Filament Cuff:

  • In your slicer, scale just the Z axis height to slightly less than the inside width of your spool. (The original height in the STL file is 2").
  • The original X and Y scale is about right for an 8" diameter spool. (The cuff is springy, so it will shrink down as you use the filament.) However, for larger spools you may want to increase the X & Y scale together.
  • Print with 2 shells and a 0.40mm line width. If you scale up X & Y, you should also scale up the line width by the same amount.
  • Slip the cuff over your filament roll, with the free end of the filament coming out of the side with the handle.
  • To roll up extra filament, hold onto the handle while rotating the spool - the wound up filament will disappear under the cuff.
  • Make sure you store your spool with the free end of the filament overlapping the cuff.

comments.text: The spool holder really works well. Its simple, effective and didn't take long to print. However, I wish I hadn't wasted three hours printing the cuff though...it just doesn't work in my application.  If you spool from the bottom, the cuff just slides out and interferes with the travel of the filament.

A replacement arm for the dji Firewheel quadcopter.  
The photo shows the version before the published one that doesn't have a hole for the motor wires.  
I struggled to get the screw holes in exactly the right place, but I think they are ok now.  If not, let me know.  It's about a four and a half hour print on my Replicator so I haven't bothered to re-check, but I'm sure I'll be printing another soon, given my piloting skills!

This needs to be a solid as you want to make it and printed with support.  I printed it at 50% fill, with two shells and it doesn't flex. It also weighs less that the original arm.  
However, in crashes it does break easier than the original ones, but if you don't crash, that's not a problem.  
The motor mount holes should be drilled out to 3.5mm and just replace the centre plate screws with some self tapping ones to get a good grip on the plastic.

comments.text: How do I put this together?
comments.author: joshtheimpaler

comments.text: The large, curved ramp gets glued onto the back wall so that it is flush with the bottom of the main body. The smaller triangular ramp goes on the front wall, just above the front opening. The main cylindrical turning mechanism has to be put into the machine and held into place while the nubs and crank are inserted through the side holes to hold it in place.

description.text: At our first qualifier of last season we didn't make it through the first round of inspections for a few reasons, one being that we didn't have a clear 'Main Robot Power' label. Fill ratio varies to your preference, but I think ours was ran at 15%.

author: CNSTMA

description.text: Fluke 323 DMM Dial

The GT200 is a controversial "remote substance detector" that was claimed by its manufacturer, UK-based Global Technical Ltd, to be able to detect from a distance various substances including explosives and drugs. The GT200 was sold to a number of countries for a cost of up to £22,000 per unit, but the device has been described as little more than "divining rods". The owner of Global Technical, Gary Bolton, was sentenced to seven years in prison.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GT200

This is a replication of the original device from pictures and descriptions found online. It operated in the same way as the GT200, using a swinging antenna to point to a target material indicated via "programmable cards" inserted into a reader.

description.text: This is a replacement part for the Pasquini Livia 90 espresso machine. The underside of the equipment body contains a thin plastic cover which can break. If the cover is broken, then machine is very loud when the pump is operating. This design provides a compatible replacement for the cover.

1. I had success with standard quality, two shells, and a 25% fill using black ABS filament.
  2. Use of a raft is optional.
  3. Supports are not necessary.
  4. I applied an aluminum foil backing to the side of the cover facing the boiler of the Livia to radiate heat away.
  5. Use the screws from the old cover to attach the new cover.

title: Handle for 3D print nozzle unclogging needle (and hole gauge)

description.text:
A 3D printed handle for securing a needle or thin wire while unclogging a jammed printhead nozzle.
Sometimes the nozzle of your 3D printer can become clogged when for instance a foreign dust particle travels with the filament down to the thin extrusion tip where it gets stuck.
There are several ways to solve this. One of the simplest is just to put your 3D printer in preheat-mode and push a thin wire through the nozzle, thus cleaning out whatever jammed it.
This 3D-printable handle comes in several wire-hole sizes as well as a thin-hole 3D-pring gauge so that you can easily find out what the smallest printable hole is, depending on your current print settings.
Appart from the metal wire and the handle itself, you can use a scrap length of 1.75 mm filament to jam the wire into place. Please see the instructions below.
To get hold of a thin metal wire just look around and harvest it from several every-day items, such as the thinnest string on a guitar with metal strings. Make sure that the wire is somewhat thinner then the nozzle bore hole. A common size is 0.4 mm, so a suitable wire should measure 0.3 mm. Use a calliper to find out the exact width of your wire.
This tool can also be used to measure the distance of melted plastic filament and find out at what height the plastic starts to become solid. It is useful for trouble shooting and temperature print setting adjustments.
To prevent clogging happening at all we recommend to protect the entrance opening of your 3D printers filament. This can be made by this simple 3D-printable filter: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:52203
Short video of 3D print: http://youtu.be/bl6ZIT-oAtE

Make sure to use common sense when unclogging your 3D printer with a wire. Don't touch the hot tip with your fingers to avoid getting burned. Also make sure not to wreck your machine and consult your manual and supplier if in doubt. By Creative Tools

  • Home - Things - GooglePlus - Twitter - Facebook - Youtube - Instructables - Instagram - Flickr - Vimeo - LinkedIn

See the embedded images in this things page to clearer understand the instructions below.
  • Download the file: "Hole gauge (diameter 0,5 - 1,5 mm).stl" and 3D print it on your 3D printer.
  • Take about 50 mm (two inches) of thin metal wire (i.ex. used guitar string). Maker sure the wire is thinner than the hole of your printers extruder nozzle.
  • With a pair of beak pliers, bend 2 mm of one end of the wire 90 degrees.
  • Find out which of the 11 holes is open enough for the wire to pass through.
  • The holes different diameters range from 0.5 to 1.5 mm with 0,1 mm intervals.
  • Choose the correspondent hole (i.ex. 1.0 mm) and download the handle with the same diameter, for instance: "Handle for 3D print nozzle unclogging needle 1.0 mm.stl". 3D print this file on your machine.
  • Insert the piece of wire and make sure the 90 degree bend gets inside the handles V-shaped gap.
  • Grab a piece of scrap filament and insert it into the handle to fix the wire in place.
  • Cut off the remaining piece of filament.
  • Your wire is now ready for use. Don't use it for acupuncture! ;-)

    Usage:

  • Preheat your 3D printer
  • Insert the wire carefully in the nozzle hole. NEVER USE FORCE
  • Try to feel any obtrusion and push it gently upwards
  • Unload any filament in your machine so that foreign particles are removed with the filament.

title: The better spool holder - M3D The Micro
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This spool holder is designed to:

  • Align the spool so it faces the print head (unlike the original spool holder). This helps the filament run so much better.
  • Be really sturdy. M24x3 threads match that. =)
  • Be fully printable with M3D The Micro.

This is my first released thing in which I've put more effort so all comments and improvement ideas are welcome! =)

Oh there's a #FilamentChallenge running! Ok! =)
Currently printing this thing on the M3D, pics follow..

The threads are M24x3, you might have to clean them up after printing to get them fit. (But once they do, they're awesome =)

Prints

Variation 1: Easier cleanup = easier to make

This variation can be cleaned using regular threading tools.

  • 2 x Clip v2
  • Roll

Variation 1b (Recommended): Better fit on M3D

Just printed the exact same profile used in the clip and it fits perfectly. That part was much smaller though.

  • 2 x Clip v3
  • Roll

Variation 2: Easier roll swap

This might be harder to clean. You need a left handed M24x3 tool to clean it. (Good luck, buy me one while you're at it!)

  • Clip v2
  • Clip v2 with left handed threads
  • Roll with left handed threads on the other side

Old revisions if someone prefers them

  • Clip v1

Changes

  • v2 includes a nicer looking clip with rounded edges.
  • Fixed threads being left handed on the other end of the roll
  • Well. Added that old roll version back since it might be nicer for some =D
  • v2 clip fits ok but it could be nicer. v3 clip is that. I haven't printed this yet so that's beta. SHOULD be closer to the original clip than v2. (Just very subtle adjustments here and there..)

Since it's very tight fit on the print area, print the clip with M3D with the following rotation:

Pitch: 97
Roll: 90
Yaw: 0

Roll is best printed vertically with automatic support on the bottom end.

title: Liquid Force Maxflow Kite Pump Adapter

description.text:
Valve for fitting onto pump end. This fits the Liquid Force Maxflow system. Just print, and use on your pump hose directly! After a few iterations i've found a good fit, so there is no need for any after treatment.

The small extruded pieces can be cut with a knife, as they can be difficult to print out without error, and might be too big.

This can be printed without support on most systems. I recommend ABS since it has good brigding capacity and also some flex to it (compared with PLA).

Enjoy & Feel free to share!

description.text:
This is a little ball to house an Adafruit NeoPixel mini LED. It has a hole in the top for the light to shine and a hole in the bottom for the wires to come out. The idea is to mount it in a ball socket so you can adjust its angle.

Here's the LED we're talking about : http://www.adafruit.com/product/1612

Printed 20% infill each side equator up no raft or support.

1) Solder wires onto the the LED. Data in, Data out, power & ground. Make sure the wires are as close as possible to the center of the disk.

2) Slip the bottom hemisphere up the wire and glue the PCB into the recess of the hemisphere.

3) Glue the top hemisphere onto the bottom hemisphere.

4) Mount in a socket. See the picture for an example.

title: Surfboard wall mount - Sliding nose mount for fast access

description.text:
Mount for fixing a surfboard with pointy nose and fish-tail onto a wall.

I've designed this to give quick to access the board, while remaining a very slim profile. I've seen many surfboard mounts where the board is sticking out into the room taking up a lot of space, or the board might be positioned all the way up under the ceiling, thus making it very inaccessible. People are also using big clumsy bands or rope to holding the surfboard in place. If you, like me, don't like those solutions LOOK NO FURTHER:

This design minimises the mount profile and allows fast access and fast positioning of the board on a wall-mount that lets you enjoy the look of your board!

PLEASE NOTE: This is a first edition. The curvature for the nose is not that great, and the tail only works on boards like a fish-type.

NOSEMOUNT:
The sliding nose mount is very nice and can be printed in 2 parts without support. The design prevents the mount from falling off/sliding off its wall mount, and the travel is about 5-7 cm. This allows for quick and easy removal of the board when its needed. The tolerances will also prevent the mount from sliding too easy, thus a little force is needed to lift it. This prevents the mount from sliding off by itself, but it can be slided up when its needed!
All in all Im quite pleased with the sliding mechanism. Further work is to get the curvature better for the nose.

TAILMOUNT:
The Tailmount can be printet in 1 part without support. It only works for fish-type boards, since it needs the geometry of the fish-tail to prevent the board from sliding around.

ASSEMBLY:
Simply snap the two nosemounts together. Screw the tailmount into the wall at the desired hight. Find the correct position for the nose mount when placing the board on the tailmount. Make sure the nosemount (assembled) is pressed all the way down onto the board. Make sure the mount can be slided up, and the board will be free. Install the nosemount onto the wall with screws aswell.

If the interest is big i might be able to make several editions for different boards.
Designed in SolidWorks. Please let me know if there is any comments/questions or if you would like the SolidWork Source files.
Mail at: c.sigshoj ( a ) gmail . com (Spacing to awoid bots picking up my mail) for fast response.

Enjoy your board, even when you are out of the water!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15-50%

Notes:

PRINTSETTINGS:
I recommend 0.2 mm layer height and NO Support for all the parts. It might need to be rotated in your slicer software. I always use ABS for mounts and structural prints.

description.text: Wedge to place small CMOS at FPV angle of 20 degrees.

READ DESCRIPTION. IMPORTANT INFORMATION BELOW!

This is an untested mold for a convergent divergent rocket nozzle. The side that attaches to the rocket has a radius of 7.5mm (diameter 15mm) so you can resize it to fit your rocket. The picture uploaded shows you where to cut the model so the mold can be removed after the nozzle dries. This is designed so you can use a mix of aluminum foil and resin glue to wrap around like paper mache. Remember not to put epoxy on the layer that comes in contact with the mold. KNO3 rocket fuel (Sugar and KNO3) is hot enough to burn through a few layers of aluminum foil (1 to 3) so remember to apply multiple layers if you want the nozzle to be reused. Do this at your own risk!

title: Light Socket Adapter for the Zuzanna Lamp

description.text:
This adapter is designed to work with a bare hard-wired socket you would find at a hardware store like Lowes/Home Depot.

This is the socket I used: http://www.lowes.com/pd_75121-37672-884413___?productId=3379428

Print both inner and outer parts. You'll need support on the inner part.

  • Connect wire to socket.
  • Run wire thru inner part.
  • Slide socket into opening and secure w/2 screws.
  • Take wire/inner part and run thru lamp
  • Screw outer part to inner part to secure socket to lamp.
  • Hang it. :-)

description.text:
For use on a 1" center to center pegboard. The spool dowels are 3.2" long and in two different sizes for all of those pesky filament spools! The bracket has three different slot positions. They are wide enough to create a train of dowels for multiple filament spools.

v2 just added. Changes: Higher hooks for a better catch in the pegboard, rounded the hooks

Pictures arriving soon!

GS

Print bracket laying on its side while on you build plate (should use the least amount of support material). Also would recommend with at least two shells and 25% infill or higher for the possible weight that it will be taking. Simply print the dowels and slide your filament spool onto them. Then place the dowel into the notches in the bracket.

comments.text: I was able to print the brackets and large dowel successfully but it seems like there has been a mistake with the measurements. Using a 1" centre pegboard with a gap of one unused set of holes, the space between the inner edges of the brackets is 2.2", too narrow for the dowel or the spool. When moved along one leaving a gap 2 unused holes the gap between the inner edges is 3.2", the same as the entire width of the dowel and therefore it doesn't sit on the brackets.

description.text:
Here is a remix of this fun thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:758675
I teased the switch plate and octopus apart into separate models in Meshlab and did a little smoothing of the octopus. Now you can print in two colors with dual extrusion.

Prints nice at 0.2mm layer in ABS. Support used for plate model only (due to recess behind plate), not needed for octopus. Raft recommended for ABS to avoid warpage. The spacing of the two screw holes is a little tight for my switches. It took some coaxing to get both threaded. You might want to print a partial plate first without the octopus and see if it needs to be resized slightly to fit your switch mount holes.

title: Universal Filament Spool Rollers -  using 1" PVC & printed ends for 8mm rod

description.text:
I wanted a universal spool roller for my new custom printer, with a new Diamind Hotend (3-color mixing hotend) I needed a 3 spool roller that would be easy and quick to change out filament spools - I also wanted the ability to use multiple width and diameter spools - this fit the bill perfectly and rolls amazingly easy with very little resistance.

I made the mounts to hold some extra 8mm rod I had lying around and then designed an end-cap/bushing that would fit the inside/ends of 1" PVC & would double to keep the spools from going off the edge, this allows me to cut the PVC to any width, Wrapped it up by making end mounts to hold the bar in place - I use a couple of 8mm washers at each end to keep the rollers from binding. The mounts are currently sized to fit 1" 80/20 extrusion (but could easily be adapted to many other mounts).

  • soon to follow - upgraded bushings that will hold skate board bearings inside 1"PVC (not really needed, as these spin VERY easy - but the bearing version would also work with 8mm threaded rod)

description.text: Just a another robot I designed for fun using sketchup and some postprocessing to get the body to be a solid object. Prints pretty well and the joints are tight enough to stand but forgiving enough to rotate.

I made mine from ABS, 33% fill but I'm don't think it's critical. Supports are needed and I also needed to split into 2 prints due to an inefficient layout but I wanted 2 colors anyhow so that worked fine.

print_settings.Notes:: I found better results not printing roofs on the battery lower compartment and no floor on the battery upper compartments.

description.text:
V6.0 is here! Check it out in my other prints. I will leave V2.0 published since almost none f the parts are compatible with the new, improved version, also this one is currently a bit bigger.
NOTE THIS IS AN OLD VERSION!
I made a version of this collar a few years ago before I got my 3D printer. I wanted to see what a 3D version would look like when printed.
Updated 10/17/15
If you make one of these feel free to add your input on printability and design.

NOTE THIS IS AN OLD VERSION!
Added battery screw for reference. It is hard to print, you can order the real deal from McMaster Carr.
The Battery compartment has been designed to accommodate a 123A Lithium battery. It lasts many hours, and is readily available. The Battery door and Battery compartment have holes in them so you can use a needle or a pin as a hinge pin.

I used IDE ribbon cable wires for the LEDs. I have included a wiring diagram for the LEDs, The resistors can go on either side of the LED, and there are many places to put them in the model. The parts include conduits for the wire. to power the LED on the side that does not have a battery compartment, pass a wire through the conduit just under the hinge.

K&J Magnetics
12.6mmx5mm Disks from N35 ZD3 Amazingly strong given their size. (4 Required)

Digikey supplied the Resistors and battery components
CF14JT10K0CT-ND 8.3 Ohm 1/4W Resistor (2 Required)
36-5223-ND CONTACT BATT W/TABS POSITVE A/AA (1 Required)
36-5201-ND CONTACT BATT W/TAB NEG SPRG A/AA (1 Required)

SuperbrightLEDS.com
RL5-R3545 2.6V 50MA Clear Red LEDS. (2 required)

Mc Master Carr
Part Number 91390A183 Set Screw (1 Required)

Conduit
From an LED snake light I found on Amazon http://amzn.com/B003SSAEZ2

Red "Lights"
Acrylic Round Rod, Translucent Red, 1/2" Diameter, 2' Length
https://www.amazon.com/Acrylic-Round-Translucent-Diameter-Length/dp/B00EVBTQ18/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1476491970&sr=8-1&keywords=acrylic++rod+red

The battery compartment is in two parts, an upper, and a lowerThis way it can be printed without supports.

You may notice that the Chain anchor is missing from this design. I did not print mine on the printer, Instead I took a pice of flat bar steel and glued (Welded actually) a half a link of chain to it. The sides of the collar have places to put magnets in to hold the chain anchor on. This way if anyone pulls too hard on the chain it pops off, protecting you and the prop! I got plastic chain at Lowes, and painted it silver.

Please note, this is NOT a screen accurate model, some liberties were taken, and parts were modified to simplify construction, and printing.

The parts in this model an be printed with minimal/no supports. I included some star shaped mouse ears to aid with Bed adhesion when printing with ABS. They should be removed as a part of the finishing process

Printer:

Monoprice Makerbot clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

15%

Notes:

50% infill on adjusters, and hinge parts

I print in ABS on a heated glass bed, washed with ABS doped Acetone. I also cover my printer with a large Garbage bag especially for the larger parts.

I found better results not printing roofs on the battery lower compartment and no floor on the battery upper compartments.

Designed in Fusion 360!
Uses "123" size batteries.

remixed_from.author: Jon_S
remixed_from.title: Bearing for Printrbot Metal Plus Filament Spool Holder

title: Rollers for Printrbot Metal Plus Filament Spool Holder

description.text:
This is an upgrade for my Printrbot Metal Plus spool holder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:675439)

The narrow roller bearings tend to lean over, and occasionally the spools become dislodged.

These rollers overcome those shortcomings and are much easier to load.

First to print my original spool holder: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:675439

Purchase 80 (for a single spool) or 160 (for dual spools) 3/16-inch bearing balls. Amazon has packs of 144 for $5.45: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000AO5KOW/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

For one roller pair (front and back) print:

2 x 'spool_holder_roller_bar' (I used 0.3mm layers, 25% fill, 3 perimeter shells) - green in the exploded view
4 x 'spool_holder_roller_bearing_p1' (I used 0.2mm layers, 25% fill, 3 perimeter shells) - magenta in the exploded view
4 x 'spool_holder_roller_bearing_p2' (I used 0.2mm layers, 25% fill, 3 perimeter shells) - yellow in the exploded view
4 x 'spool_holder_ring' (whatever layer height you want) - cyan in the exploded view

Insert your balls (note: I am not responsible for any injuries caused by misinterpretations of this step) through the small hole in 'spool_holder_roller_bearing_p2', and place 'spool_holder_roller_bearing_p1' over the top. In my print, the fit was tight and no glue was needed.

Place a 'spool_holder_ring' over this sub-assembly with the tapered edge towards the conic part (so they match). Then insert this in to one end of the 'spool_holder_roller_bar'.

Repeat for the other end of the roller.

If you have a dual extruder set up, or just want to have two spool holders, then double everything above to make 4 rollers, and print 6 x 'spool_holder_roller_spacer'. One spacer goes between each side-by-side roller pair to prevent the rollers from rubbing against each other, and then one on each outside end to prevent the rollers from rubbing against the main spool holder pieces.

title: Pelican ProGear™ Voyager phone case holster repair part

description.text:
Practical use of our 3D Printer -

Problem: broke the retaining part on my cell phone holster - so I used my calipers, measured out the old pard, then designed a replacement part in CAD - then printed out the part on the 3Dprinter and put my phone holster back together --> result, phone holster works again until factory replacement part (under warranty) arrives - end result totally cool 30min repair !!!

My son's holster broke on the same weak part 6 months ago . . . now his is fixed too . . .

NOTE: Called Pelican Warranty to get the "Lifetime Warranty" phone case/holster repaired and each time I can only get their voice mail (called 6 times, left detailed slow VM messages each time, with my phone number, and email requesting to please contact me) - after a week of waiting and still NO RESPONSE . . . repaired it myself, hopefully the'll call and stand behind their warranty soon, until then, just glad I have a 3D printer

comments.text: nice work on the repair part. I had same problem with my clip as well. I am currently trying to improve the strength of the part. If you print it flat with the large disk portion on the bed the part is weekend due to the layer bond. I am currently trying to print standing on its side with supports to get the layers flowing the other direction to eliminate the weakness of the layer bonders on the tabs. Will let you know how it goes.

remixed_from.author: SFoskett
remixed_from.title: Intel NUC Disk and Ethernet Base

title: Parametric OpenSCAD Base for Intel 5th Generation NUC.

description.text:
This is an OpenSCAD design for a base for a 5th generation NUC.
I'm currently awaiting its manufacture with Shapeways. It may need updating before it's perfected.

The depth of the sidewalls can be altered and there are features that can be enabled or disabled, such as vesa holes, a logo, ethernet port etc. Parameters exist for the size of most things, so you can adapt the size and shape of things to your needs.

There have been three updates to the code. The current one is version 4, which is now with Shapeways.

Version 1 imported a dxf for the logo and had straight through holes for the mounting screw, which you would need to provide.

In version 2, I changed the screw channels to accept the screws that come with the nuc. They sit in hole with the screw head at the same level as with the provided base.

The logo was changed to use a polyline logo generated from inkscape. So no file importing. Remove or insert the logo of your choice.

Update: It came back from Shapeways. The screw channels line up perfectly with the board mount points, which is nice because I had to measure it. Intel don't provide mechanical information on the position of the nuc board relative to the nuc case.

There were two issues:

(1) The sides lines up nicely, but the corners weren't a good fit because the corner radius on the thing was smaller than the corner radius on the nuc. I've increased it to 8 mm from 6 mm.

(2) The hole in the vesa mounting points was small enough (r=0.9mm) that it closed up when printed. Also it's a little too small to thread in the vesa mounting screw provided with the nuc. I've increased it to r=1.2mm.

These changes are in the third version of the file.

Another Update:

After hacking at the lip corners in the model with a knife to test out the changes, if found it still wasn't a perfect fit because there are two dimples on the inside of the front face of the case that I hadn't found before. Curse you Intel for not publishing complete diagrams. Putting two cutouts on the front lip for these dimples makes it fit perfectly. Version 4 adds the necessary cutouts. Also, after spending a little time with the calipers, I've change the vesa mounting hole internal radius to 1.1mm. A little too small is better than a little too large.

Version 4 is going to Shapeways (bye bye $50) . Hopefully it will turn out fine and will be the final version.

comments.text: Great, great work! Thanks for putting in the time to design this.

title: Printrbot Metal Plus Extended Fan Mount

description.text:
I wanted to upgrade the fan mount to allow for a taller high performance fan. So I based this design off the original Printrbot shroud and extended it out beyond the bridge.

The holes for the mount need a little work as they get filled in at a few levels but a drill could correct for the issues rather quickly.

EDIT:
I added two pictures after installing this fan mount.

A few things that have come up since installing the mount. The taller fan I got is hitting the cabling on the machine. So its not ideal but does work. I have tried a few things to get around this issue but have decided to use a cable chain to replace the current wiring setup. The current design does put stress on the cables next to the extruder and was the reason my other fan stopped working.

Link to the cable chain: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/printrbot-metal-plus-cable-chain

description.text:
These need to be epoxied onto the ends of 1/2" Loc-Line coolant hose to make flexible mounts. It's the same line GoPro uses on there $50 clamp mount. You can make your own for $20-$30 at most.

The line can be made to any length but 1' long is perfect for most uses. Don't use 1/4" loc-line it's not stiff enough (I made that mistake already).
Print solid, then use plenty of epoxy (I highly recommend J-B Weld or J-B Quick). Just don't skimp out on the epoxy, put plenty.

title: "Venti-Pi": virtual 1TB Raspberry Pi Linux laptop; automotive media server; surveillance server

description.text:
Goal: invisible 1TB Raspberry-Pi computer: create an affordable, powerful, 1TB Linux computer/edge-node blending into our everyday world!
Applications: turn any laptop/PC into a 1TB Raspberry-Pi computer; 1TB Linux server that easily mounts into any car; 1TB mobile media server for on-the-go entertainment, data backup; etc.

Note: printed parts were developed on a Makerbot Rep2 (PLA), with default settings except no rafts, no bridges.

Parts List:

  1. 3D print: "venti-pi_ring.stl"
  2. 3D print: "venti-pi_mount_8screw", or "venti-pi_mount_4screw" if you don't procure items #11 below (R-Pi mounting screws)
  3. Raspberry-Pi 2
  4. WD PiDrive kit: 1TB hard disk drive with power-delivery accessories designed for Raspberry Pi: http://store.wdc.com/promo/96259800 (US); http://store.wdc.com/promo/96259700 (UK). NOTE: 35% discount coupon!! (latest code: WDPIDRIVE1TB)
  5. USB-WiFi dongle, such as: http://www.amazon.com/Edimax-EW-7811Un-150Mbps-Raspberry-Supports/dp/B003MTTJOY/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1441428845&sr=8-1&keywords=edimax
  6. Compact 5V USB battery, such as: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00P7N0320?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00
  7. USB cable with right-angle connector, such as: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003YKX6W2?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00
  8. USB connector adapter, such as: http://www.amazon.com/Black-Female-Micro-Adapter-Converter/dp/B00BWFYBPC/ref=pd_sim_147_24?ie=UTF8&refRID=1CNAQEYMQ3YHY858FPTE
  9. Retractable USB cable, such as: http://www.amazon.com/DROID-Incredible-DataSync-Retractable-Cable/dp/B004AUSD50/ref=sr_1_2?s=wireless&rps=1&ie=UTF8&qid=1441427122&sr=1-2&keywords=retractable+usb+cable&refinements=p_85%3A2470955011
  10. M3x5 flat-head screw (qty-3) for disk drive mounting, such as: http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000NHXOMG?psc=1&redirect=true&ref_=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00
  11. (optional, see item #2 above): M2.2x4 screw (qty-4) for Raspberry-Pi mounting, such as mcmaster.com part number 96817A861
  12. (almost forgot!): beverage cup (is designed to fit Starbuck's Venti cup)

Assembly (after loading SW below): assemble parts per photos attached. Item 8 can be eliminated if you can splice/solder the WD PiDrive cable to item #7. The battery (item #6 above) is not absolutely required- it can be replaced by a 5V USB source such as a phone charger, car cigarette lighter adapter, etc.

Software:
Attach a keyboard, mouse and monitor temporarily for SW installation.

To make a virtual Pi laptop:

  1. Install Raspbian OS onto WD PiDrive (per instructions provided with WD PiDrive kit).
  2. Install xrdp remote access service onto R-Pi with PiDrive and set up Windows laptop: https://www.jeremymorgan.com/tutorials/raspberry-pi/how-to-remote-desktop-raspberry-pi/
  3. In #2 above you'll need a network access point. The OS and xrdp service will automatically connect to one access point (SSID) upon power up (i.e. without monitor, keyboard and mouse). It's easiest to use your smartphone's hotspot as the access point. Alternatively, you can use your home WiFi router, but if you leave home and want to connect to a different access point you'll need to change the SSID.

Headless server:
Venti-Pi can be implemented as a portable headless server, such as a surveillance-cam recorder; torrent download server; automobile server, entertainment media file server; phone/tablet/computer back-up server; local webserver; etc. There are many free Raspberry-Pi app images available on sites such as raspberrypi.org, instructables.com, etc.

Slight nuisance: I keep picking up my Venti-Pi computer to take a sip!

I made this after having a breakage of the antenna fitting from the receiver module inside the goggles.
The construction of these goggles leaves a lot to be desired, removing and refitting antennas to the goggles inevitably caused the SMA fitting to break off the PBC, I was able solder it back but after seeing the fragile nature of the construction I decided to make this support.
Note you will need a short SMA pigtail lead with a right angle chassis mount fitting on the outer end, the one I have came from BangGood and cost a few dollars as well as some double sided foam core tape to stick it on with.
This odd looking contraption has certainly made the goggles more robust however they no longer fit in the original case. (That's a pain) it also means the antenna is mounted a little further away from your head in theory improving performance, in practice the setup performs no worse than original.

I printer this in PLA, colour of your choice (black matches the goggles) I used 60% infill anything around this figure should be fine.
Orientate it upside down on your print bed, no support required.
